title: Introduction to Web Development
description: A comprehensive course covering HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and modern web frameworks. This course includes 50 detailed units organized into 5 chapters with 2 sections each.

units.title: What is HTML?
units.content:
What is HTML?

HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard markup language for creating web pages. It describes the structure of a web page semantically and originally included cues for the appearance of the document.

HTML elements are the building blocks of HTML pages. With HTML constructs, images and other objects such as interactive forms may be embedded into the rendered page.

units.title: HTML Document Structure
units.content:
HTML Document Structure

Every HTML document follows a basic structure:

  • DOCTYPE declaration
  • HTML root element
  • HEAD section (metadata)
  • BODY section (visible content)

Understanding this structure is essential for creating valid HTML documents.

units.title: HTML Tags and Elements
units.content:
HTML Tags and Elements

HTML tags are the hidden keywords within a web page that define how your web browser must format and display the content.

Most tags have an opening tag and a closing tag. For example: <p>This is a paragraph</p>

Some tags are self-closing, like <br /> and <img />.

units.title: HTML Attributes
units.content:
HTML Attributes

Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements. They are always specified in the start tag and usually come in name/value pairs like: name="value"

Common attributes include:

  • id - unique identifier
  • class - CSS class name
  • style - inline CSS styling
  • src - source for images/scripts
  • href - hyperlink reference

units.title: Basic HTML Elements
units.content:
Basic HTML Elements

Let's explore the most commonly used HTML elements:

  • Headings: <h1> through <h6>
  • Paragraphs: <p>
  • Links: <a>
  • Images: <img>
  • Lists: <ul>, <ol>, <li>
  • Divisions: <div> and <span>

These elements form the foundation of web page content.

units.title: Introduction to Semantic HTML
units.content:
Introduction to Semantic HTML

Semantic HTML introduces meaning to web pages rather than just presentation. Semantic elements clearly describe their meaning to both the browser and the developer.

Examples of semantic elements: <article>, <section>, <nav>, <header>, <footer>.

units.title: Header and Navigation Elements
units.content:
Header and Navigation Elements

The <header> element represents introductory content or navigational links. The <nav> element defines a set of navigation links.

These elements help screen readers and search engines understand the structure of your page better.

units.title: Article and Section Elements
units.content:
Article and Section Elements

The <article> element represents independent, self-contained content. The <section> element defines sections in a document.

Use <article> for blog posts, news articles, or forum posts. Use <section> to group related content together.

units.title: Footer and Aside Elements
units.content:
Footer and Aside Elements

The <footer> element represents footer content, typically containing copyright information, contact details, or links. The <aside> element defines content aside from the main content (like a sidebar).

units.title: Benefits of Semantic HTML
units.content:
Benefits of Semantic HTML

Using semantic HTML provides numerous benefits:

  • Improved accessibility for screen readers
  • Better SEO (search engine optimization)
  • Easier code maintenance
  • Clearer code structure
  • Better browser and assistive technology support

Always prefer semantic elements over generic <div> elements when appropriate.

units.title: What is CSS?
units.content:
What is CSS?

CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation of a document written in HTML. CSS describes how elements should be rendered on screen, on paper, or in other media.

CSS saves a lot of work by controlling the layout of multiple web pages all at once.

units.title: CSS Syntax and Selectors
units.content:
CSS Syntax and Selectors

A CSS rule consists of a selector and a declaration block:

selector { property: value; }

Common selectors include:

  • Element selectors: p, h1
  • Class selectors: .classname
  • ID selectors: #idname
  • Attribute selectors: [type="text"]

units.title: Colors and Backgrounds
units.content:
Colors and Backgrounds

CSS provides multiple ways to specify colors:

  • Named colors: red, blue
  • Hexadecimal: #FF0000
  • RGB: rgb(255, 0, 0)
  • RGBA: rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5)
  • HSL: hsl(0, 100%, 50%)

Background properties allow you to set background colors, images, and more.

units.title: Text Styling
units.content:
Text Styling

CSS offers extensive text styling options:

  • Font family, size, and weight
  • Text color and alignment
  • Text decoration and transformation
  • Line height and letter spacing
  • Text shadows and effects

Proper text styling enhances readability and visual appeal.

units.title: Box Model Fundamentals
units.content:
Box Model Fundamentals

The CSS box model describes the rectangular boxes generated for elements in the document tree. Each box has:

  • Content area
  • Padding (space inside border)
  • Border
  • Margin (space outside border)

Understanding the box model is crucial for layout design.

units.title: Display Property
units.content:
Display Property

The display property specifies how an element is displayed:

  • block - takes full width
  • inline - flows with text
  • inline-block - hybrid behavior
  • none - hidden from view
  • flex - flexible box layout
  • grid - grid layout

units.title: Positioning Elements
units.content:
Positioning Elements

CSS positioning properties:

  • static - default positioning
  • relative - positioned relative to normal position
  • absolute - positioned relative to nearest positioned ancestor
  • fixed - positioned relative to viewport
  • sticky - hybrid of relative and fixed

units.title: Flexbox Layout
units.content:
Flexbox Layout

Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout method for arranging items in rows or columns. Key concepts:

  • Flex container and flex items
  • Main axis and cross axis
  • Justify-content and align-items
  • Flex-direction and flex-wrap
  • Flex-grow, flex-shrink, flex-basis

Flexbox makes responsive layouts much easier.

units.title: Grid Layout
units.content:
Grid Layout

CSS Grid is a two-dimensional layout system. It enables you to create complex layouts with rows and columns:

  • Grid container and grid items
  • Grid lines, tracks, cells, and areas
  • Grid template rows and columns
  • Grid gap for spacing
  • Auto-placement and named areas

units.title: Responsive Design
units.content:
Responsive Design

Responsive web design makes web pages look good on all devices. Key techniques:

  • Flexible grids and layouts
  • Flexible images and media
  • Media queries for different screen sizes
  • Mobile-first approach
  • Viewport meta tag

Responsive design is essential for modern web development.

units.title: What is JavaScript?
units.content:
What is JavaScript?

JavaScript is a high-level, interpreted programming language that makes web pages interactive. It's one of the core technologies of the World Wide Web, alongside HTML and CSS.

JavaScript enables dynamic content updates, multimedia control, animated images, and much more.

units.title: Variables and Data Types
units.content:
Variables and Data Types

JavaScript variables can be declared using var, let, or const. Data types include:

  • Primitives: string, number, boolean, undefined, null
  • Objects: arrays, functions, objects
  • Symbol and BigInt (ES6+)

Understanding data types is fundamental to programming in JavaScript.

units.title: Operators and Expressions
units.content:
Operators and Expressions

JavaScript supports various operators:

  • Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, %
  • Comparison: ==, ===, !=, !==, <, >
  • Logical: &&, ||, !
  • Assignment: =, +=, -=, *=
  • Ternary: condition ? true : false

Operators combine values and variables to produce results.

units.title: Control Flow
units.content:
Control Flow

Control flow statements determine the execution path of your code:

  • if, else if, else - conditional execution
  • switch - multi-way branching
  • for, while, do...while - loops
  • break and continue - loop control

Mastering control flow is essential for writing effective programs.

units.title: Functions
units.content:
Functions

Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. JavaScript supports:

  • Function declarations
  • Function expressions
  • Arrow functions (ES6)
  • Parameters and return values
  • Default parameters
  • Rest parameters and spread syntax

Functions are fundamental building blocks in JavaScript.

units.title: Arrays and Array Methods
units.content:
Arrays and Array Methods

Arrays are ordered collections of values. JavaScript provides powerful array methods:

  • push(), pop(), shift(), unshift()
  • map(), filter(), reduce()
  • forEach(), find(), some(), every()
  • slice(), splice(), concat()

units.title: Objects and Properties
units.content:
Objects and Properties

Objects are collections of key-value pairs. Working with objects:

  • Object literal notation
  • Accessing properties (dot and bracket notation)
  • Adding and deleting properties
  • Object methods
  • Object destructuring (ES6)
  • Object.keys(), Object.values(), Object.entries()

units.title: Scope and Closures
units.content:
Scope and Closures

Understanding scope is crucial for JavaScript:

  • Global scope vs local scope
  • Function scope vs block scope
  • Lexical scoping
  • Closures - functions that remember their lexical environment
  • Practical uses of closures

Closures are a powerful feature enabling encapsulation and data privacy.

units.title: Asynchronous JavaScript
units.content:
Asynchronous JavaScript

JavaScript handles asynchronous operations through:

  • Callbacks
  • Promises (ES6)
  • Async/await (ES2017)
  • Event loop and call stack
  • setTimeout and setInterval

Asynchronous programming is essential for handling API calls and user interactions.

units.title: Error Handling
units.content:
Error Handling

Proper error handling makes applications robust:

  • try...catch...finally blocks
  • Throwing custom errors
  • Error types and error objects
  • Promise error handling with .catch()
  • Async/await error handling

Always anticipate and handle potential errors in your code.

units.title: Understanding the DOM
units.content:
Understanding the DOM

The Document Object Model (DOM) is a programming interface for HTML documents. It represents the page structure as a tree of nodes that can be manipulated with JavaScript.

The DOM allows JavaScript to:

  • Change HTML content
  • Modify HTML attributes
  • Change CSS styles
  • Create and remove elements
  • React to events

units.title: Selecting Elements
units.content:
Selecting Elements

JavaScript provides multiple methods to select DOM elements:

  • getElementById() - select by ID
  • getElementsByClassName() - select by class
  • getElementsByTagName() - select by tag name
  • querySelector() - select with CSS selector
  • querySelectorAll() - select all matching elements

units.title: Modifying Elements
units.content:
Modifying Elements

Once selected, elements can be modified:

  • textContent and innerHTML - change content
  • setAttribute() and getAttribute() - manage attributes
  • style property - modify CSS styles
  • classList - add/remove/toggle CSS classes
  • value - read/write form input values

units.title: Creating and Removing Elements
units.content:
Creating and Removing Elements

Dynamically manage DOM structure:

  • createElement() - create new elements
  • createTextNode() - create text nodes
  • appendChild() - add child elements
  • insertBefore() - insert at specific position
  • removeChild() - remove child elements
  • replaceChild() - replace elements

units.title: Traversing the DOM
units.content:
Traversing the DOM

Navigate the DOM tree structure:

  • parentNode and parentElement
  • childNodes and children
  • firstChild and lastChild
  • nextSibling and previousSibling
  • closest() - find nearest ancestor matching selector

units.title: Introduction to Events
units.content:
Introduction to Events

Events are actions that happen in the browser, such as clicks, key presses, or page loads. JavaScript can listen for and respond to these events.

Common event types:

  • Mouse events: click, dblclick, mouseenter, mouseleave
  • Keyboard events: keydown, keyup, keypress
  • Form events: submit, change, focus, blur
  • Document events: DOMContentLoaded, load

units.title: Event Listeners
units.content:
Event Listeners

Add event listeners to respond to events:

  • addEventListener() - attach event handler
  • removeEventListener() - detach event handler
  • Event handler functions
  • Multiple listeners on same element
  • Event listener options (capture, once, passive)

Event listeners enable interactive web applications.

units.title: Event Object
units.content:
Event Object

When an event occurs, an event object is passed to the handler containing information about the event:

  • event.type - type of event
  • event.target - element that triggered event
  • event.currentTarget - element with listener
  • event.preventDefault() - cancel default action
  • event.stopPropagation() - stop event bubbling

units.title: Event Bubbling and Capturing
units.content:
Event Bubbling and Capturing

Events propagate through the DOM in two phases:

  • Capturing phase: event travels from root to target
  • Bubbling phase: event travels from target back to root

Event delegation leverages bubbling to handle events efficiently on multiple elements.

units.title: Form Events and Validation
units.content:
Form Events and Validation

Handle form interactions and validate user input:

  • Submit event and preventing default submission
  • Input and change events
  • Focus and blur events
  • Client-side validation techniques
  • Displaying validation errors
  • Form data collection and processing

Proper form handling improves user experience.

units.title: Why Use Frameworks?
units.content:
Why Use Frameworks?

Modern JavaScript frameworks provide numerous benefits:

  • Component-based architecture
  • State management
  • Virtual DOM for performance
  • Developer tooling and ecosystem
  • Reusable components
  • Simplified complex UI development

Frameworks accelerate development and improve code maintainability.

units.title: Popular Frameworks Comparison
units.content:
Popular Frameworks Comparison

Overview of leading JavaScript frameworks:

  • React: Component library by Facebook, virtual DOM, JSX
  • Vue: Progressive framework, easy learning curve
  • Angular: Full-featured framework by Google
  • Svelte: Compiler-based approach, no virtual DOM

Each framework has strengths for different use cases.

units.title: Components and Props
units.content:
Components and Props

Components are reusable building blocks of UI:

  • Function components vs class components
  • Props for passing data to components
  • Component composition
  • Prop validation and default values
  • Children props

Well-designed components make applications scalable and maintainable.

units.title: State Management
units.content:
State Management

Managing application state is crucial for complex apps:

  • Local component state
  • Lifting state up
  • Context API for global state
  • State management libraries (Redux, MobX, Zustand)
  • Immutable state updates

Proper state management prevents bugs and improves performance.

units.title: Routing and Navigation
units.content:
Routing and Navigation

Single-page applications need client-side routing:

  • React Router, Vue Router, Angular Router
  • Route definition and parameters
  • Nested routes
  • Programmatic navigation
  • Route guards and authentication
  • Lazy loading routes

Routing enables complex navigation in single-page apps.

units.title: Module Bundlers
units.content:
Module Bundlers

Module bundlers package JavaScript modules for production:

  • Webpack: Powerful, configurable bundler
  • Vite: Fast dev server, ES modules
  • Parcel: Zero-config bundler
  • Rollup: Optimized for libraries

Bundlers optimize code for production deployment.

units.title: Package Managers
units.content:
Package Managers

Package managers handle project dependencies:

  • npm: Node Package Manager (default)
  • yarn: Fast, reliable alternative
  • pnpm: Efficient disk space usage
  • Installing and managing packages
  • Package.json and lock files
  • Semantic versioning

units.title: Code Quality Tools
units.content:
Code Quality Tools

Maintain code quality with automated tools:

  • ESLint: JavaScript linting
  • Prettier: Code formatting
  • TypeScript: Static type checking
  • Jest: Testing framework
  • Pre-commit hooks with Husky

Quality tools catch bugs early and enforce consistency.

units.title: Performance Optimization
units.content:
Performance Optimization

Optimize web applications for better performance:

  • Code splitting and lazy loading
  • Minification and compression
  • Image optimization
  • Caching strategies
  • Bundle size analysis
  • Tree shaking unused code

Performance directly impacts user experience and SEO.

units.title: Deployment Strategies
units.content:
Deployment Strategies

Deploy web applications to production:

  • Static hosting: Netlify, Vercel, GitHub Pages
  • Server deployment: Heroku, DigitalOcean, AWS
  • Containerization: Docker
  • CI/CD pipelines
  • Environment variables
  • Monitoring and error tracking

Proper deployment ensures reliable application availability.
